importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The day the Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action (JCPOA) officially expired, marking the end of the 10-year nuclear deal between Iran and world powers.
The original adoption date of the JCPOA resolution (Resolution 2231), which set the 10-year timeline for the deal’s expiration.
The date when the United States unilaterally withdrew from the JCPOA under President Donald Trump, reinstating sanctions and leading to Iran's increased nuclear activity.
When the UK, Germany, and France initiated the 'snapback' process, formally re-imposing UN sanctions and effectively ending any prospect of reviving the deal.

The start of a 12-day military conflict between the US and Iran, which targeted nuclear sites and led to significant civilian casualties and damage, prompting Iran to suspend cooperation with the IAEA.
When Iranian President Masoud Pezeshkian signed legislation suspending cooperation with the IAEA, reducing nuclear transparency and verification efforts.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The 10-year period during which the JCPOA was in effect, culminating in its official termination as the deal expired on the 10-year anniversary of Resolution 2231.

keyTakeAways: Iran has formally declared that the restrictions on its nuclear programme under the JCPOA have terminated, as the 10-year deal expires.
The US unilaterally withdrew from the JCPOA in 2018, leading to increased nuclear activity in Iran and a breakdown in diplomatic engagement.
The UK, Germany, and France triggered the 'snapback' mechanism in August 2024, re-imposing UN sanctions and effectively ending any hope of reviving the deal.
Iran has suspended cooperation with the IAEA following military attacks in June 2024, citing the agency’s failure to condemn US actions and accusing it of double standards.
Despite claims of a nuclear weapons programme, neither US intelligence nor the IAEA has found evidence of Iran pursuing atomic weapons.
Iran remains skeptical of negotiating with the US due to its history with former President Donald Trump, while Western powers seek a maximalist agreement.
Iran continues to express openness to diplomacy but only if the US offers guarantees against military action.
The 12-day US-Israeli military campaign in June 2024 significantly damaged Iran’s nuclear infrastructure and intensified tensions, undermining trust in international nuclear oversight.

namedEntities.name: Iran
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A country in the Middle East with a nuclear programme under international scrutiny.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Iran is the central actor in the nuclear deal and is now asserting that it is no longer bound by restrictions, marking a shift in its nuclear posture and diplomatic stance.

namedEntities.name: Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action (JCPOA)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A 2015 nuclear agreement between Iran and world powers (China, France, Germany, Russia, UK, US) to limit Iran's nuclear programme in exchange for sanctions relief.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The JCPOA is the core framework discussed in the article, and its expiration marks a pivotal moment in global nuclear diplomacy.

namedEntities.name: United States
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A global superpower and one of the original signatories to the JCPOA.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The US withdrew from the JCPOA in 2018, leading to the collapse of the deal, and remains a key player in nuclear negotiations and tensions with Iran.

namedEntities.name: China
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A global power and one of the original signatories to the JCPOA.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: China was a signatory to the JCPOA and remains part of the international nuclear oversight framework, though it has not been prominently active in recent developments.

namedEntities.name: France
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A key European power and one of the original signatories to the JCPOA.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: France participated in the original deal and later triggered the snapback mechanism, which formally ended the agreement.

namedEntities.name: Germany
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A key European power and one of the original signatories to the JCPOA.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Germany participated in the original deal and later triggered the snapback mechanism, which formally ended the agreement.

namedEntities.name: Russia
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A global power and one of the original signatories to the JCPOA.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Russia was a signatory to the JCPOA and remains part of the international nuclear oversight framework, though it has not been prominently active in recent developments.

namedEntities.name: United Kingdom
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A key European power and one of the original signatories to the JCPOA.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The UK participated in the original deal and later triggered the snapback mechanism, which formally ended the agreement.

namedEntities.name: International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A UN agency responsible for monitoring and verifying nuclear activities globally.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The IAEA has been central to monitoring Iran’s nuclear programme and has expressed serious concern over its inability to verify Iran’s nuclear stockpile after the 2024 military conflict.

namedEntities.name: Masoud Pezeshkian
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The President of Iran, who signed legislation suspending cooperation with the IAEA in July 2024.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Pezeshkian's decision to suspend cooperation with the IAEA reflects Iran’s strategic response to US military actions and loss of trust in international oversight.

namedEntities.name: Donald Trump
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Former President of the United States, who unilaterally withdrew from the JCPOA in 2018.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Trump’s withdrawal initiated the collapse of the JCPOA and set the precedent for current US skepticism and hostility toward diplomatic engagement with Iran.

namedEntities.name: Abbas Araghchi
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Iranian top diplomat, who stated Iran does not see reason to negotiate with Europeans due to snapback.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Ahraghchi’s statement reflects Iran’s current diplomatic posture of non-engagement with Europe, citing the snapback mechanism as a justification.

namedEntities.name: Kelsey Davenport
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: An expert from the Arms Control Association, who commented on the meaninglessness of 'termination day' due to snapback.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Davenport’s analysis provides expert context on the symbolic and practical irrelevance of the deal's termination due to snapback implementation.

namedEntities.name: Ali Vaez
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Director of Iran project at International Crisis Group, who assessed the deal as 'lifeless' and the snapback as 'officially burying' the agreement.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Vaez’s expert evaluation underscores the practical collapse of the JCPOA and the current diplomatic deadlock.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Iran has declared that the nuclear restrictions imposed under the 2015 Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action (JCPOA) have officially terminated, marking the end of a 10-year agreement. Despite Iran’s claim of continued commitment to diplomacy, the deal effectively collapsed due to the United States’ 2018 unilateral withdrawal, followed by the UK, Germany, and France triggering the 'snapback' mechanism in August 2024, which re-imposed UN sanctions and formally ended negotiations. The US-Israeli military campaign in June 2024, which targeted Iranian nuclear sites and killed over 1,000 civilians, further eroded trust and led Iran to suspend cooperation with the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA). Neither US intelligence nor the IAEA has found evidence of Iran pursuing nuclear weapons, though concerns remain. Iran remains skeptical of talks with the US, citing past political hostility, while European powers now seek to restart negotiations. Experts argue that the termination of the JCPOA is largely symbolic, as its practical end was sealed by the snapback process, and the agreement remains politically and strategically inactive.
title: Iran says restrictions on nuclear programme ‘terminated’ as deal expires
